Posts.Content: Kath, I can really understand how worried and anxious you are, I too was facing chemo, but my surgeon sent off tonthe states for an ONcotype DX test, my result came back as a score was 11 which meant that chemo would not be of benefit to me. I am one of three sisters, my twin and I were diagnosed within two weeks of each other, she didn’t need an axillary clearance or chemo as her Oncotype DX score also came back as 11. My other sister was diagnosed 3 months later and had to have Chemo, but instead of having a high dise every three weeks she had 12 cycles, one a week which was a lower dose, she had minimal side effects, they will give you anti sickness tablets to help you, she also kept her hair on her head (she wore the cold cap); although she lost her eyebrows and eyelashes, but these returned almost immediately. Much love Amanda xxx
Posts.Title: Lymph node recurrence after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi. I am wondering if it is possible to have a recurrence of cancer in your lymph nodes in the same armpit after a total axillary clearance. Can’t find any information about this, thanks in advance for any insight. Amanda x
Posts.Title: Lymph node recurrence after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Thank you Dreamthief. Yes it’s definitely nerve damage which I was warned of before the op... my arm will never feel the same again, but a small price to pay in the circumstances. I don’t believe it's cording just the actual scar which is a quite raised, but i do agree with the scar tissue, its been a year on the 14th August. I am assuming that my first mammogram and appt is due soon, but haven’t heard from the hospital yet, when it comes through and I have a formal appointment I will probably get peace of mind, thank you x

I am one of three sisters, my twin and I were diagnosed within two weeks of each other, she didn’t need an axillary clearance or chemo as her Oncotype DX score also came back as 11. My other sister was diagnosed 3 months later and had to have Chemo, but instead of having a high dise every three weeks she had 12 cycles, one a week which was a lower dose, she had minimal side effects, they will give you anti sickness tablets to help you, she also kept her hair on her head (she wore the cold cap); although she lost her eyebrows and eyelashes, but these returned almost immediately. Posts.Title: Lymph node recurrence after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Kath, my op went well, i stayed in overnight and was due to stay another night as I was exhausted due to only being able to get one hour of sleep. I had my drains in for 10 days, a community nurse visited My home to help with my drains and take measurements of how much was draining off, you will definitely need help in the first 2-4 weeks with dressing and various activities. Begin your exercises the next morning after your operation to get movement. Do as much or as little as you can, it took me a good 4 weeks to get reasonable movement, with some of the ecercises you can feel the drain pulling inside which hurt me a little, but just take care and know your limits. I found the neck movements valuable in reducing and minimsing stiffness. I also had difficulty sleeping for several months as my arm was how I described really painful and uncomfortable, i knew that there was something wrong with my arm within approx 2 weeks as my upper arm felt swollen, heated, tingly and uncomfortable, my BC nurse measured my arm and noted a difference in size and then referred me to the Lymphoedema clinic, I had an appointment within 2-3 weeks and I am now under their care. I wear a compression sleeve daily to manage the swelling and uncomfortable feeling, as a result the size of my arm has reduced, although I will have to keep wearing the sleeve. Hope this helps xxx

Posts.Title: Lymph node recurrence after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hello and thank you both for your help and the image which i found very helpful. Yes this is an hypothetical question. I had full clearance in my left armpit up to level three. They no longer do Radiotherapy on the armpit after a full clearance due to the high risk of developing Lymphoedema (although I developed it within in two weeks if surgery anyway).  Whilst a full clearance removes tissue containing the lymph nodes remaining nodes are left in your arm I believe but they are microscopic? In August it will be a year since I had it done, my armpit and back are still numb, my armpit as a deep long scar running through it and still hurts and feels lumpy, which is the reason I am wondering if anything could have been left behind/began to grow... they removed just 12 nodes (so I didn’t have a lot anyway?!).
Posts.Title: Lymph node recurrence after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Boobylou, glad to hear you had the all clear, that must have been a relief x i am also now used to the numbness, i only had a WLE and a second op where a total of 12 lymph nodes were removed with 2 containing cancer. X

Posts.Content: Thank you ALL so very much for your personal stories, advice and reassurances-it means so much to me. I laughed out loud at some of them.... especially the hooha's and doodah's!  I had a meeting with my nurse today and that along with your fantastic support has put me in a much better place. I will thankfully be able to wear my own knickers and dressing gown, so haapy about that. Just need some good news tomorrow for my twin sister who two weeks ago discovered a lump also, she had a mammogram yesterday and will be having an ultrasound tomorrow- hoping its a cyst, but it doesn't feel like it so we are extremely worried. They have fast tracked her because of my condition so that was good. Thank you all so much again - sending you all my love, Amanda

Posts.Title: Starting chemo!!

Posts.Content: I had a mammogram on the 13th June and an ultrasound with a biopsy on the 20th June which confirmed BC in the lower inner quadrant of my left breast. I had a lumpectomy on the 24th July. I have checked my breast this evening and I have found a small pea size lump under my areola of my left breast... under the blue dye that is still there. As I have recently had a mammoth and ultrasound, should I ignore this or contact my breastcare team? Thanks, Amanda
Posts.Title: Found another lump!

Posts.Content: Thank you Kenla and Boobylou.  Thank you for your concern and advice. I contacted my nurse yesterday morning and she arranged for my consultant to see me yesterday afternoon. He agreed there was a definite lump, he arranged for an immediate ultrasound- the outcome is that is a bit of tissue - i think she called it necrosis? Relieved! I think this is reality now! i really appreciate your fabulous support.
Posts.Title: Found another lump!

Posts.Content: Hi Mistymoly, only just seen your response. How are you feeling? You are right... I definitely was worried and predicting the worst!! It was good that my BC nurse and consultant acted so quickly and understood my concern which my consultant could also feel. I am very very worried about recurrence as it's all I'm reading/hearing of at the moment - I am also feeling very very down at the moment, I don't feel I have any purpose at the moment, I am crying all the time and very miserable.   I have a hospital Appt this morning with a Lymphoema specialist as I have arm swelling-which is also getting me down. Xxxx
Posts.Title: Found another lump!

Posts.Content: I started taking TEVA brand of Tamoxifen early October 2017, I will be on it for 10 yrs, (and my twin sister and I have got on with them extremely well). we were gutted to learn on the 28th April (directly from TEVA) that they have discontinued producing them... see response below: I therefore need to research for another brand of Tamoxifen, and would love to hear from you about which brands have the least side effects and which brands to avoid... although I understand that what may be suitable for one person, may not be for another. One of the brands that I have researched is Wockhardt, which looks like my best option at this time. Thank you very much Amanda x Letter from TEVA... Please accept my sincere apologies that this product has been discontinued and is no longer available for sale. We constantly review our product portfolio and look at the products that sit within it. This is something we do routinely and the decision to discontinue any product is made only where necessary, due to supply and demand. Please accept my apologies once again as we do fully understand the importance of all of our products to patients and this decision is never made lightly. I apologise that the only advice we are able to give you would be to speak to your GP in relation to alternative products. With Kind regards Customer Solutions Team
Posts.Title: TEVA Tamoxifen DISCONTINUED!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Helen. Thanks for that. Hope Wockhart continues to work for you. It would be good to hear from you again if you do experience any changes. I have enough Teva left for a couple of months, thankfully, which will allow me time for research. thank you again, and all the very best to you Amanda xxx
Posts.Title: TEVA Tamoxifen DISCONTINUED!!!!

Posts.Content: Thanks Sugartc. Appreciate your inout xxx
Posts.Title: TEVA Tamoxifen DISCONTINUED!!!!

Posts.Content: I truly understand how you feel but don’t panic Basonk... i was down going down the chemo route. My cancer was stage 2b as it had spread to my lymph nodes and I had to have an axillary dissection. My surgeon sent my tissue off to the US for Oncotype DX trsting-it came back as 11 which meant that I would not benefit from chemo in terms of protection against recurrence. Its good they are doing this for you. I am now scheduled to see my radiation oncologist on 2nd Oct. i hope this will be the same for you too xxxx
Posts.Title: Thought I knew my treatment plan until today

Posts.Content: Thats really good to know. Thank you Aspen. I will speak to my GP. Amanda xxxx
Posts.Title: TEVA Tamoxifen DISCONTINUED!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, thanks for replying. I will have my results of my first ultrasound and biopsy on Thursday. Just feeling very worried. The Radiologist was very confident that its cancer and the Dr I saw immediately afterwards was talking about a lumpectomy and radiation treatment... but if course all of this depends on my take of cancer etc. Amanda
